Just as an aside to the programatic finding of test cases, the build tool
Ant has support
for junit. Effectively, you specifiy a set of files (test cases) that you
want to be run, and
and sends only those cases to junit for testing. Its a quick way to start
automatic testing.
It handles filtering by name and directory.

Its output is in plain text or xml, although its a little clumsy to work
with.

Example:

<junit printsummary="no" haltonfailure="no">
    <formatter type="plain"/>
       <classpath>
           <pathelement
path="${testrun.classpath}:${testbuild.classpath}:${test.classes}:${oraclejd
bc.home}/classes111.zip"/>
       </classpath>
       <batchtest>
            <fileset dir="${test.classes}">
                 <include name="**/promo/test/*Test.class"/>
                 <exclude name="**/All*.class"/>
            </fileset>
       </batchtest>
  </junit>
  -----Original Message-----
  From: mrettig@... [mailto:mrettig@...]
  Sent: Monday, February 05, 2001 4:52 PM
  To: junit@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: Re: [junit] Test Suites Useless?



  Bob Sartin wrote:
  >>I'd love to hear positive experiences.

  On my last project, we used a test finder exclusively, rather than using
suites. I found several positives.

  1. We never had an instance where we thought a test was being run when it
wasn't due to a bad suite.
  2. Developers new to the Junit framework only had to know about TestCases,
and not Suites.
  3. Encouraged better package modularity.
  4. There are no suites that have be maintained/Debugged.
  5. Every TestCase is automatically part of the whole system test upon
creation without have to modify or create a suite.

  >>When we created the TestSuite classes initially, we ordered the tests
  >>so that the more "primitive" classes are tested first.
  Dependencies do present an interesting situation. My compiler knows how to
resolve these things, why can't my testing framework? The simple way to do
this would be to simply add a way for dependencies to be declared as part of
a TestCase. This could also be dictated by package structure, but I think
that is putting too much responsibility on packaging. Ideally, the testing
framework would be able to discover these things during runtime.

  >>So, if we use an automated test finder, it needs to have a way to
  >>categorize tests and selectively include/exclude certain categories.
  This can easily be done using a naming convention to differentiate
classes, or you can subclass TestCase to make cases for different platforms.
It depends how you want to discover tests. Do you want to do it based on
filename? Or actual class definition? Or some combination?

  Regards,
